name: UnionArgonaut Condition ProfileAndUSCoreConditionEncounterDiagnosisProfile
title: Union of null And US Core Condition Encounter Diagnosis Profile

element.short: left: Argonaut Condition Profile; right: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses
element.definition: left: Use to record detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses recognized by a clinician. There are many uses including: recording a diagnosis during an encounter; populating a problem list or a summary statement, such as a discharge summary.; right: \-

constraint.human: Condition.clinicalStatus SHALL be present if verificationStatus is not entered-in-error. Condition.clinicalStatus SHALL NOT be present if verification Status is entered-in-error

mapping.map: < 243796009 |Situation with explicit context| : 246090004 |Associated finding| = ( ( < 404684003 |Clinical finding| MINUS ( << 420134006 |Propensity to adverse reactions| OR << 473010000 |Hypersensitivity condition| OR << 79899007 |Drug interaction| OR << 69449002 |Drug action| OR << 441742003 |Evaluation finding| OR << 307824009 |Administrative status| OR << 385356007 |Tumor stage finding|)) OR < 272379006 |Event|)

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: left: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.; right: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: left: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.; right: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: left: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.; right: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: left: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.; right: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: left: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).; right: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: left: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.; right: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: left: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.; right: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: left: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.; right: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: left: Additional Content defined by implementations; right: Extension
element.definition: left: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.; right: An Extension
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition:
left: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.; right: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

element.definition: left: This records identifiers associated with this condition that are defined by business processes and/or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).; right: Business identifiers assigned to this condition by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.
element.requirements: left: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.; right: Allows identification of the condition as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

element.definition: Indicates the patient who the condition record is associated with.

element.short: left: Encounter when condition first asserted; right: Encounter created as part of
element.definition: left: Encounter during which the condition was first asserted.; right: The Encounter during which this Condition was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: left: This record indicates the encounter this particular record is associated with.  In the case of a "new" diagnosis reflecting ongoing/revised information about the condition, this might be distinct from the first encounter in which the underlying condition was first "known".; right: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter. This record indicates the encounter this particular record is associated with.  In the case of a "new" diagnosis reflecting ongoing/revised information about the condition, this might be distinct from the first encounter in which the underlying condition was first "known".

element.definition: Individual who is making the condition statement.
A date, when  the Condition statement was documented.
element.comment: The Date Recorded represents the date when this particular Condition record was created in the EHR, not the date of the most recent update in terms of when severity, abatement, etc. were specified.  The date of the last record modification can be retrieved from the resource metadata.

element.short: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
element.definition: Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.
element.requirements: 0..1 to account for primarily narrative only resources.

binding.description: Valueset to describe the actual problem experienced by the patient

mapping.map:
code 246090004 |Associated finding| (< 404684003 |Clinical finding| MINUS
<< 420134006 |Propensity to adverse reactions| MINUS 
<< 473010000 |Hypersensitivity condition| MINUS 
<< 79899007 |Drug interaction| MINUS
<< 69449002 |Drug action| MINUS 
<< 441742003 |Evaluation finding| MINUS 
<< 307824009 |Administrative status| MINUS 
<< 385356007 |Tumor stage finding|) 
OR < 413350009 |Finding with explicit context|
OR < 272379006 |Event|

element.short: left: complaint | symptom | finding | diagnosis; right: category codes
element.definition: A category assigned to the condition.
element.comment: The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts.

binding.description: left: Extended category code valueset to support the intent of the separate concepts of problems and health concerns; right: A category assigned to the condition.

mapping.map: 'problem' if from PRB-3. 'diagnosis' if from DG1 segment in PV1 message

element.short: left: active | relapse | remission | resolved; right: active | recurrence | relapse | inactive | remission | resolved
element.definition: The clinical status of the condition.
element.comment: The data type is CodeableConcept because clinicalStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

element.short: left: provisional | differential | confirmed | refuted | entered-in-error | unknown; right: unconfirmed | provisional | differential | confirmed | refuted | entered-in-error
element.definition: The verification status to support the clinical status of the condition.
element.comment:
verificationStatus is not required.  For example, when a patient has abdominal pain in the ED, there is not likely going to be a verification status.
The data type is CodeableConcept because verificationStatus has some clinical judgment involved, such that there might need to be more specificity than the required FHIR value set allows. For example, a SNOMED coding might allow for additional specificity.

mapping.map: .code (pre or post-coordinated in)  Can use valueNegationInd for refuted

element.definition: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
element.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

binding.description: A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.

mapping.map: Can be pre/post-coordinated into value.  Or ./inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="severity"].value

element.short: Estimated or actual date,  date-time, or age
element.definition: Estimated or actual date or date-time  the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician.
element.comment: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur.

element.short: left: If/when in resolution/remission; right: When in resolution/remission
element.definition: The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.
element.comment: left: There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.  If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid.; right: There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.  If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid.  When abatementString exists, it implies the condition is abated.

mapping.map: .effectiveTime.high or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="age at remission"].value or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ]source[classCode=CONC, moodCode=EVN].status=completed

element.definition: Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments.

constraint.human: Stage SHALL have summary or assessment

element.definition: left: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).; right: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific.

binding.description: Codes describing condition stages (e.g. Cancer stages).

element.definition: Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based.
The kind of staging, such as pathological or clinical staging.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes describing the kind of condition staging (e.g. clinical or pathological).

element.definition: left: Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed.; right: Supporting evidence / manifestations that are the basis of the Condition's verification status, such as evidence that confirmed or refuted the condition.
element.comment: The evidence may be a simple list of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both.

constraint.human: evidence SHALL have code or details

element.definition: A manifestation or symptom that led to the recording of this condition.

binding.description: Codes that describe the manifestation or symptoms of a condition.

element.definition: Links to other relevant information, including pathology reports.
The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself.
element.comment: left: May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.; right: Only used if not implicit in code found in Condition.code. If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite].  May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.definition: Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry  for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis.
Indicates the patient or group who the condition record is associated with.
element.requirements: Group is typically used for veterinary or public health use cases.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The recordedDate represents when this particular Condition record was created in the system, which is often a system-generated date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Individual who recorded the record and takes responsibility for its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry  for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis.
